Part A: Describe one claim the King of Kongo makes in his letter.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The people of Kongo kidnap other people.

  • Captured people are sold for Portuguese goods.

  • People are taken during the night to avoid being recognized.

  • People are branded with fire.

  • Noblemen and their relatives are vulnerable to being kidnapped and enslaved.

  • It is the duty of the King to do justice and restore freedom to the captured people of Kongo.

The response accomplishes the task set by part A of the question.

Note: The Sudanic Empires include Ghana, Mali, and Songhai. While they flourished at different times, a comparison between the Kingdom of Kongo and any of these empires is acceptable.

Part B: Describe one similarity or difference between the Kingdom of Kongo and another Sudanic empire between the thirteenth and sixteenth centuries.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The Kingdom of Kongo and Sudanic empires (Ghana, Mali, or Songhai) traded goods across long distances.

  • The Kingdom of Kongo and Sudanic empires (Ghana, Mali, or Songhai) were influenced by non-native religious beliefs brought in via trade.

  • The Kingdom of Kongo and Sudanic empires (Ghana, Mali, or Songhai) used religious ties to help strengthen trade.

  • The Kingdom of Kongo adopted Christianity, while the Sudanic empires (Ghana, Mali, or Songhai) adopted Islam.

The response accomplishes the task set by part B of the question.

Part C: Explain how interactions with Portugal affected the Kingdom of Kongo in the sixteenth through eighteenth centuries.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The Kingdom of Kongo became wealthier through increased trade with Portugal for goods including ivory, salt, copper, and textiles,

  • The Portuguese colonized islands off the coast of Africa and established plantations that used enslaved people from the Kingdom of Kongo as labor. This created a model for enslavement that would later be used by the United States.

  • The Kingdom of Kongo was dependent on Portugal and traded enslaved people for military assistance.

  • Interaction with Portugal resulted in the destabilization of the Kingdom of Kongo. The use of African captives as currency with the Portuguese resulted in increased violence and loss of leadership in Kongo.

The response accomplishes the task set by part C of the question.

Part D: Explain how religious traditions of Afro-descendants in the Americas were affected by interactions with other cultures in the eighteenth through twentieth centuries.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • African spiritual practices, including veneration, divination, and collective singing and dancing, were blended with European cultures to form syncretic religions. Afro-descendants who were enslaved in the Americas often performed spiritual ceremonies from these syncretic faiths to strengthen themselves before leading revolts.

  • In the United States, religious traditions became more diverse with the immigration of Afro-Caribbean immigrants into African American communities. Many of these people were Catholic, Anglican, and Episcopalian and hailed from non-English-speaking islands.

  • The Nation of Islam (NOI) was founded in Detroit in 1930, blending basic beliefs and practices of Islam with mythology and Black Nationalist ideology. Many African Americans converted to Islam and changed their surnames to Muslim names.

The response accomplishes the task set by part D of the question.
